body: Hi! Thank you for your contribution! Please re-check all issue template checklists - unfilled issues would be closed automatically. And do not forget to [join our slack](https://join.slack.com/t/catalyst-team-core/shared_invite/zt-d9miirnn-z86oKDzFMKlMG4fgFdZafw) for collaboration.

dear @ssktotoro, thanks for the issue
Am I correct, that we could do something like 
```python

class IRunner:
    def run(self, *args, **kwargs):
        # here is the trick
        if self.profile:
           with torch.profiler.profile(
            activities=[
                torch.profiler.ProfilerActivity.CPU,
                torch.profiler.ProfilerActivity.CUDA,
            ],
        
            # In this example with wait=1, warmup=1, active=2,
            # profiler will skip the first step/iteration,
            # start warming up on the second, record
            # the third and the forth iterations,
            # after which the trace will become available
            # and on_trace_ready (when set) is called;
            # the cycle repeats starting with the next step
        
            schedule=torch.profiler.schedule(
                wait=1,
                warmup=1,
                active=2),
            on_trace_ready=trace_handler
            # on_trace_ready=torch.profiler.tensorboard_trace_handler('./log')
            # used when outputting for tensorboard
            ) as p:
                self.run_experiment()
        else:
            self.run_experiment()
```
?
So, just make a code injection [here](https://github.com/catalyst-team/catalyst/blob/master/catalyst/core/runner.py#L800) or. [here](https://github.com/catalyst-team/catalyst/blob/master/catalyst/core/runner.py#L779#L791)?

The example is taken from the PyTorch docs https://pytorch.org/docs/master/profiler.html.

That's the easy version to play with.  The more annoying bit of what I envision is passing the profiler rather than a flag in order to have it be fully configurable.  This means that we validate the profiler after its passed, but that's not too bad either.

There is definitely a trade-off here, a lot of the arguments to the profiler we can extract from the environment, e.g.: whether to profile both the CPU and CUDA or only CPU. Furthermore, in most instances, it would probably be beneficial to set flags like profile_memory=True and use a standard warmup for the profiler. The question is then: do we want to make it as easy as possible on the user by introducing a flag? Or do we let the user decide how they want to initialize the profiler, but provide minimal examples for profiling in such a way that an inexperienced PyTorch user can profile their code as well?

A quick note regarding your code example @Scitator, we would also need a p.step() in on_batch_end(), so maybe the profiler should be an attribute of the IRunner class (if the profile argument is set to True)

Speaking about the profiler, we could do the following. For the Python API:
```python
runner.train(
    profiler: Union[bool, Profiler] = None
)
```
So, you could use the default with `True` flag or your own with precise specification.

Nevertheless, I am not sure about CustomRunner or Config API cases here....

One possbile solution could be to add `get_profiler` (just like [`get_engine`](https://github.com/catalyst-team/catalyst/blob/master/catalyst/core/runner.py#L320)) to the IRunner and check it during [`on_experimen_start`](https://github.com/catalyst-team/catalyst/blob/master/catalyst/core/runner.py#L604#L616):
```
self.profiler = self.get_profiler()
```

And yup, we could add a necessery `p.step()` during `on_batch_end` ;)

@Scitator what are your thoughts on adding record functions: `with profiler.record_function("_run_batch"):` for the hierarchical runner functions like: `_run_epoch()`, `_run_loader()`, `_run_batch()`, etc. These record functions allow us to accurately time those sub-functions of the runner and help the user understand what part of the runner is the bottleneck to their training/inference speed. This would also deprecate `TimerCallback` because we could replace it with record functions.

We could update the whole Runer with such an injectns (`with profiler.record_function("_run_{XXX}"): run_XXX()`), yeah.
Nevertheless, is it possible to wrap it with the Callback? Would it cost some measure bias during profiling?

We could wrap it in a callback and those callbacks would probably be measured by the profiler, so I don't think it would be biased. I just wonder whether wrapping it in a callback wouldn't make it harder to use the profiler, because the user would first have to instantiate the profiler, pass it to the runner and then also use a separate callback.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
